body:
Nice work @huonw!

> I think the platform specific intrinsics should go in their own extern ABI (i.e. not "rust-intrinsic")

I agree, not having the namespace of "simd_" made me a tad uneasy.

> I think it would be very nice for this to land without requiring the RFC to land first, because of the first point, and because this is the only way for any further work to happen/be experimented with, without requiring people to build/install/multirust a compiler from a custom branch.

I would personally be ok with this, but I'm curious to hear what others think as well? Also, do you think the RFC basically has "broad consensus" modulo minor details by this point? If there are still some somewhat contentious decisions here and there it may be worth waiting a little longer before landing this, but if we're all in agreement pretty much then any future minor updates can be easily reflected here (as everything is unstable anyway).

cc @rust-lang/lang
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #27176) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #27382) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

Ok, rebased and updated to be better, including 
- intrinsics for casts and arithmetic (i.e. operators don't work automatically for SIMD types: they have to go via the normal traits)
- a special `platform-intrinsic` extern ABI for these intrinsics,
- type-checking the platform-specific intrinsics,
- some general refactorings

(I'm updating the RFC to ensure it matches the things I've learned while implementing, as we speak.)
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #27551) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
Looking good to me! Just a minor nit so far
Updated (will rebase in a bit), includes addressing the nit, adding a pile of platform intrinsic definitions (gets much of x86-64 from SSE to AVX2 and ARM NEON), and adding tests.
(There's still some more tests I want to add, particularly run-pass tests making sure the various generic intrinsics behave sanely.)

If I use

```
#[cfg(any(target_feature = "sse2", target_feature = "neon"))]
```

it works fine for x86-64, but for `--target=i686-unknown-linux-gnu` it doesn't match, even though it should (the generated code is using SSE2 instructions). The workaround is to copy the `rustc` command line from cargo and add `-C target-feature=+sse2`, and then it matches.

(This was before your latest rebase, but I think the relevant code didn't change.)
Rebased and more tests added.

> --target=i686-unknown-linux-gnu it doesn't match, even though it should (the generated code is using SSE2 instructions).

It seems like the compiler assumes any i686 CPU Rust will be run has SSE2, which isn't strictly guaranteed. Clang seems to also make this assumption by default for `-m32`, while GCC doesn't, falling back to the x87 instructions. Not sure exactly where we should go with this, but the current arrangement is the conservative default (opt-in except for the cases where it is truly guaranteed: SSE2 on x86-64, and NEON on AArch64).

> It seems like the compiler assumes any i686 CPU Rust will be run has SSE2, which isn't strictly guaranteed. Clang seems to also make this assumption by default for -m32, while GCC doesn't, falling back to the x87 instructions. Not sure exactly where we should go with this, but the current arrangement is the conservative default (opt-in except for the cases where it is truly guaranteed: SSE2 on x86-64, and NEON on AArch64).

So I ask myself, how does clang does it? It has to `#define __SSE2__` (and others). The answer is that [it's based on the CPU type](http://llvm.org/viewvc/llvm-project/cfe/trunk/lib/Basic/Targets.cpp?view=markup). The i686 targets in `rustc_back::target` all set `options.cpu` within the `Target` to `"pentium4"` or newer, and according to the clang code that has at least SSE2.

But rust doesn't use clang; the _real_ code for that is at `src/llvm/lib/Target/X86/X86.td`, where the processor `pentium4` sets a `FeatureSSE2` flag (which when set sets a `FeatureSSE1` flag, and so on).

The ideal way would be to ask LLVM since it's the authoritative source, but I wonder why clang doesn't do it; either clang needs more information than LLVM has, or it's not easily possible to ask LLVM for the correct list of features given the CPU model. Another option would be to duplicate what clang does, and have a hand-written map from the processor name to its SIMD features. It would have to be manually updated every time LLVM is updated, which isn't too much work but would be easy to forget.

> The ideal way would be to ask LLVM since it's the authoritative source, but I wonder why clang doesn't do it; either clang needs more information than LLVM has, or it's not easily possible to ask LLVM for the correct list of features given the CPU model. Another option would be to duplicate what clang does, and have a hand-written map from the processor name to its SIMD features. It would have to be manually updated every time LLVM is updated, which isn't too much work but would be easy to forget.

Obviously asking LLVM would be great, and @alexcrichton asked about doing this above. We investigated, it didn't seem easy at all. The current approach is basically a very restricted version of what clang does: http://llvm.org/viewvc/llvm-project/cfe/trunk/lib/Basic/Targets.cpp?view=markup#l2505

Very nice work @huonw! I've got some final comments but they're mostly just stylistic or nitpickity here and there. I'm ok landing this ahead of the RFC as it'll help developing the `simd` crate externally, and it looks like the final direction we go in will probably largely be along these lines anyway.

cc @rust-lang/lang for the SIMD differences and @rust-lang/compiler as this touches quite a bit of code. I'm basically ready to r=me, but just wanna make sure there's a heads up.
Updated, addressed review.
